title: Allow Section View, not only clause view, on Record level
author: Anika Pinnell
content:
Current Challenge: When utilizing templates that contain multiple sections and clauses, our current system highlights only the individual modified clauses during the review process. This isolated view does not provide a comprehensive understanding of the changes within the context of the entire section.
 
Proposed Solution: We suggest the implementation of a feature that allows for the highlighting of the entire section in which any clause has been modified. This would enable a holistic overview, preserving the logic and coherence of the entire chapter, rather than limiting the focus to a single sentence or clause.
Benefits:
Enhanced Contextual Understanding: Experts can evaluate the full impact of changes within the context of the entire section, ensuring that the logic and flow of the document remain intact.Improved Review Efficiency: A section overview, adjacent to the clause overview, would streamline the review process, allowing for quicker identification of changes and their implications.Increased Flexibility: Our use case involves plain text fields between marked clauses that are editable by users without highlighting changes. The proposed feature would accommodate this unique requirement, preventing the loss of crucial information during the review.
We have encountered challenges where the lack of section highlighting leads to an incomplete picture for our experts, hindering their ability to assess the full extent of modifications and their ramifications on the chapter as a whole.
 
We believe that the addition of this feature would be a valuable asset not only to our organization but also to other users of your platform who may face similar challenges.

title: Tracking and Managing Contractual Obligations
author: Vikram Chakrabarty
content: Obligations emerge out of a contract as part of the negotiation process. When two (or more parties) negotiate the various terms and clauses in a contract, what they are really doing is determining the obligations of both parties involved in the contract. Here's a simple but effective and fairly validated idea for an effective obligation management solution, where you start with the usual contract negotiation, arrive at the final set of negotiated clauses at signatures, tag those negotiated clauses as which ones need to be tracked as obligations, categorize the obligations, assign an accountable and responsible owner to the obligations, determine how the obligation should be assessed for compliance (in most cases it would be an assessment survey questionnaire) and lastly determine the number of times in a year you would want to assess the obligatino for compliance. Now the system automatically creates TASKS that send an email notification to the responsible (and accountable) persons as the tasks fall due. The email contains a link to an assessment survey (leveraging Salesforce communities here) which can be filled out by the responsible person and submitted. This submission is captured on the obligation and based on the submitted responses, the accountable person can determine whether the obligation is in compliance, at risk of non compliance or is already in jeopardy.

title: Prevent creation of multiple DocuSign envelopes at the same time
author: Joseph Franklin
content:
After user selects the file and clicks send for signatures and then immediately clicks back, because of lightning latency issue, agreement page does not immediately refresh, and still shows status as pending/ready for signatures with send for signatures button still showing up. Now the user can send for signatures again, select file and go through the process all over resulting in 2 envelopes getting created (I have noticed if the back button is clicked too soon, status of the first envelope remains blank). However, Docusign console shows 2 envelopes with the status 'Waiting for others'. In this scenario, the recipient would receive two emails with separate envelopes and is able to open and sign both. After signatures are completed, batch jobs that run at every 15 min interval in the background look for any signed envelopes and insert the signed document under files, then update the agreement status to fully signed and update the envelope status to Completed. If the recipient had signed both envelopes in this case, we see both signed docs under Files section, but the Agreement/Envelope Status update fails.


I think we can put in some logic to prevent creation of multiple envelopes at the same time or almost immediately after first envelope is created.

This has been a consistent and major issue for Fannie Mae (Case#'s 00105836 & 00115083) even after several user trainings and needs some control to built in to the product.
